bookCover.coverDescription: An Interactive book on cell, its type and structures of cell for grade 5 students.

params.audioNotSupported: Your browser does not support this audio

params.text:
The bodies of living beings are made of tiny units called cells. Different types of plants and animals are found around us. Some of them are made of only one cell, whereas most of the plants and animals are made of many cells. The cells in living beings can be compared with the bricks in a building. Cells are very small in size and cannot be seen with our naked eyes. Therefore, we use a compound microscope to see the detailed structure of cells. The basic, structural and functional unit of life is called a cell. Various activities like growth, reproduction, respiration, excretion, etc. occur inside the cell.

Plants and animals differ greatly in their shapes and sizes. Similarly, cells also differ in their shapes. They may be rectangular, hexagonal, oval, spherical, polygonal, etc. Most of the cells are microscopic. They are very small in size. However, some plant cells and animal cells can be seen with our naked eyes.

params.audioNotSupported: Your browser does not support this audio

params.text:
• In 1665, Robert Hooke first observed cells by looking at cork under an early compound microscope.
  • The word cell comes from the Latin word cellula, which means small compartment.
  • Cells are the smallest biological unit of life found in all organisms.
  • When many cells of the same kind are together in a group, it's called tissue.
  • It’s estimated the average human body has about 40 trillion cells.

params.question: The cell was first discovered by an English scientist Robert Hooke in 1665 AD.

params.audioNotSupported: Your browser does not support this audio

params.text:
There are lots of different types of cells. Each type of cell is different and performs a different function. All living things have cells. These tiny building blocks work together to create simple bacteria as well as more complex organisms, such as people and animals. Cells are similar to factories with different labourers and departments that work towards a common objective. Various types of cells perform different functions. Based on cellular structure, there are two types of cells:

  • Prokaryotic Cells

The prokaryotic cell is a simple, small cell with no nucleus or internal compartments. Organisms made from prokaryotic cells are very small, such as bacteria. Some prokaryotes such as bacteria have a region within the cell where the genetic material is freely suspended. This region is called the nucleoid. The cell size ranges from 0.1 to 0.5 µm in diameter.

  • Eukaryotic Cells

These cells are typically a lot bigger and more complex than prokaryotic cells. These cells have identifiable internal components in addition to a genuine nucleus which houses the cell's DNA. This broad category involves plants, fungi, protozoans, and animals. The size of the cells ranges between 10–100 µm in diameter.

questions:
1) A cell that has a nucleus is *eukaryotic* cell.
(eukaryotic / prokaryotic)

2) Plants and animal cells are examples of *eukaryotic* cells.
(eukaryotic / prokaryotic)

3) Bacteria have a region within the cell where the genetic material is freely suspended called *nucleoid*.
(nucleoid / DNA)

4) *Prokaryotic* cell size ranges from 0.1 to 0.5 µm in diameter.
(eukaryotic / prokaryotic)

metadata.title: Q4- Fill in the correct answers.

params.audioNotSupported: Your browser does not support this audio

params.text: Though cells are very small in size, they are made of various parts such as cell wall, cell membrane, mitochondria, vacuoles, plastids, centrosome, endoplasmic reticulum, ribosomes, etc. A brief description of various parts of a cell is given below:

Cell Wall

  • Cell Wall

The outermost covering layer of plant cells is formed by the cell wall. It is a hard and rigid structure made of a non-living substance called cellulose. Animal cells do not have a cell wall.

Functions

  • The cell wall provides a fixed shape to the plant cell.

  • It also protects the internal parts of plant cells.

  • The cell wall allows all substances to enter or leave the cell.

params.audioNotSupported: Your browser does not support this audio

params.text:
Cell Membrane

  • Cell Membrane

The cell membrane forms the outermost covering layer of animal cells. It is a thin, living and elastic membrane. The cell membrane is found just inside the cell wall in plant cells.

Functions

  • It provides an outer boundary to an animal cell and protects internal parts of the cell.

  • The cell membrane allows only selected substances to enter or leave the cell.

params.audioNotSupported: Your browser does not support this audio

params.text:
Cytoplasm

  • Cytoplasm

The jelly-like substance found in a cell is called cytoplasm. It is made of water, carbohydrate, protein, fat droplets, etc. Cytoplasm is enclosed by the cell membrane and surrounds the nucleus. The cytoplasm consists of cell organelles and inclusions.

Functions

  • Cytoplasm provides space for various cell organelles and inclusions.

Do you know?

  • The living bodies present inside the cell are called cell organelles, e.g. nucleus, mitochondria, plastids, etc.

  • The non-living bodies present in a cell are called inclusions, e.g. vacuoles, fat droplets, etc.

params.audioNotSupported: Your browser does not support this audio

params.text:
Nucleus

  • Nucleus

Nucleus is the most important cell organelle present in the cytoplasm. It is round or spherical in shape. It is made of nuclear membrane, nucleoplasm, nucleolus and chromosomes. The nucleus is found nearly at the centre in animal cells but it is slightly shifted towards the side in plant cells.

Functions

  • Nucleus controls various activities of a cell.

  • It takes part in cell division.

Do you know?

  • Chromosomes are thread-like structures present in the nucleus of a cell.

  • Nucleus is called the director or controller of a cell.

params.audioNotSupported: Your browser does not support this audio

params.text:
Endoplasmic Recticulum

  • Endoplasmic Recticulum

The space between the cell membrane and the nuclear membrane is occupied by an irregular network of channels which is called endoplasmic reticulum. It is of two types, i.e. smooth endoplasmic reticulum and rough endoplasmic reticulum. Ribosomes are attached to the surface of the rough endoplasmic reticulum.

Functions

  • Endoplasmic reticulum forms the supporting framework of the cell.

  • It provides mechanical support to the cytoplasm.

params.audioNotSupported: Your browser does not support this audio

params.question: Select the function of cytoplasm from the given options.

params.audioNotSupported: Your browser does not support this audio

params.text:
Mitochondria

  • Mitochondria

Mitochondria are spherical, oval or thread-like cell organelles present in the cytoplasm. They have an outer membrane and an inner membrane. Mitochondria are the sites of energy production and storage. Therefore, they are called the power houses of a cell.

Functions

  • Mitochondria produce energy required for the cell.

  • They store energy.

params.audioNotSupported: Your browser does not support this audio

params.text:
Vacuoles

  • Vacuoles

Vacuoles are non-living, fluid-filled structures found in the cytoplasm. In animal cells, vacuoles are smaller but more in number, whereas they are larger but less in number in plant cells. Vacuoles are filled with water, waste materials, carbohydrates, minerals, etc.

Functions

  • Vacuoles help in excretion.

  • They help in the growth of the cell.

params.audioNotSupported: Your browser does not support this audio

params.text:
Ribosomes

  • Ribosomes

Ribosomes are very small round or spherical structures present in the cytoplasm. They are also found attached to the tubes of rough endoplasmic reticulum.

Functions

  • Ribosomes help in protein synthesis.

params.audioNotSupported: Your browser does not support this audio

params.text:
Plastids

  • Plastids

Plastids are spherical, oval or disc-shaped structures found in plant cells. They are located in the cytoplasm. In plant cells, plastids are of three types. They are Chloroplast, Chromoplast, and Leucoplast.

Chloroplasts include green pigment called chlorophyll. The leaves and young stem of plants appear green due to the presence of chlorophyll.

Chromoplasts are found in petals of flowers and pericarp of fruits. They contain colourful pigments.

Leucoplasts are found in the underground parts of plants such as roots. They contain colourless pigments.

Functions

  • Chloroplasts trap the solar energy and help in photosynthesis.

  • Chromoplasts give colour to petals and fruits.

  • Leucoplasts store food.

Do you know?

  • Chlorophyll traps the solar energy and helps the green plants in photosynthesis.
  • The process of making food by green plants in their leaves is called photosynthesis.

params.audioNotSupported: Your browser does not support this audio

params.text:
Centrosome

  • Centrosome

Centrosome is a very small protoplasmic structure present near the nucleus in the cytoplasm. It is found only in animal cells.

Functions

  • Centrosome helps in cell division of animals cells.

params.audioNotSupported: Your browser does not support this audio

params.textField:
1) Power house of a cell *Mitochondria*.
2) Helps in excretion *Vacuoles*.
3) *Nucleus* cell's control center.
4) *Cell membrane* selectively allows things to get in and out of the cell.
5) *Cell organelles* tiny components present in the cytoplasm.
*prokaryotic* cells lack nuclear membrane.
6) A group of similar cells combine to form *tissue*.

questions:
1) The fundamental and functional units of life are called *cell*.

2) *Mitochondria* produce energy required for the cell.

3) Eukaryotic cells have a well-developed *nucleus*.

4) *Cell wall* is absent in animal cell.

5) The cell organelles which is found only in an animal cell is *centrosome*.

6) Instrument is used to observe cells *microscope||compound microscope*.
